label.name: This example illustrates the concept of using expl...
label.intro:
This example illustrates the concept of using exploring a data frame. We illustrate this using the Niger Climatic Data.
Recall that this is daily climatic data which gives measurements for four stations: Agades, Niamey Aero, Birni Nâ€™Konni, and Zinder. There are 14 variables. The first set of variables are information about the daily data:

  • Name: The name of the station

  • date: The date for that row of data

  • year: The year for that row of data

  • month_abbr: The month for that row of data

  • doy: Which day of year is it for that year (from 1-366)

  • day_in_month: The day in the month for that row of data


Then eight different elements are then given in this data. These are:

  • tmin: Minimum temperature (celsius)

  • tmax: Maximum temperature (celsius)

  • rain: Rainfall (mm)

  • hmax: Maximum humidity

  • hmin: Minimum humidity

  • sunh: Hours of sunshine

  • ws: Wind speed

  • wd: Wind direction

Let's say the task is to find variables that can predict the rainfall.

We can explore this data, and the relationships between variables. We might want to do this through PivotTables. For example, by looking at the relationship between the Station and rainfall:

Sum of rain Column Labels
Row Labels Agades Birni N'Konni Niamey Aero Zinder Grand Total
1940 567.9 567.9

1963 174.6 460.6 473.5 362.5 1471.2

1976 106.6 547.3 589.4 442.3 1685.6

1980 156.1 481.5 428.4 523.8 1589.8
Grand Total 5600.5 20535.4 23597.5 17484.9 67218.3

There are a few stand-out points. First, we only have rainfall values for Niamey Aero in 1940-1944, but not the other three stations. In addition, the total rainfall tends to be much smaller for Agades than the other stations. Is this due to missing values, or due to differences in climate? We can answer this by digging into the data further, and additionally by speaking to experts in the field who may know more about the expected rainfall for the regions. For example, lets look at the proportion of missing rainfall values from 1945 to 1980 in the data:

  Name           rows missing_rows proportion_missing
  <fct>         <int>        <int>              <dbl>
1 Agades        13149          737             0.0560
2 Birni N'Konni 13149          810             0.0616
3 Niamey Aero   14976          776             0.0518
4 Zinder        13149          725             0.0551
It doesn't appear that there are more missing values in Agades than the other stations. However, it may still be that the values are missing in Agades in a rainy season, but in a non-rainy season for the other stations. We can explore this as well. Figure 1 displays a plot with each column giving the variable, and each row the observation. We can see the distribution of missing values in this data.

Generally, it looks as if the values are missing around the same time for rainfall between stations. For the other elements, we can see a similar pattern between the different stations - wind speed and wind direction was not measured for the first few years for any data set, and sunshine hours was frequently missing in the first decade or so!

Figure 1: Missing values in the Niger data, split by Station.

This is only a brief exploration, but we could dig in deeper by looking by month or year for these distributions of missing values.

We can additionally have a quick glance over all the variables in our data (Figure 2). We see that there are more observations in Niamey Aero. It appears there is no data for any of the other three stations in the first five years.
Year is normally distributed - this is an example where it might make sense to instead visualise year as a factor! We knew before that there would be a spread of year equally between 1940 and 1980.
Our "Month" variable is looking ok, but we can see it is in alphabetical order. This might cause problems later in the analysis, so we would want to reorder this variable to be in the correct month order.
DOY and Day in Month do not give any new insights beyond what was expected.
Our elements is where these visualisations get more interesting. We can see the distribution of the different elements across the whole data. Rainfall, for example, is a very skewed variable with the outliers skewing the graphic and resulting in a less clear distribution.


Figure 2: Distribution of the variables in the Niger data

We can continue to explore the data, for example, by looking at the relationship between Rainfall and the other values. We may do this by looking at a scatterplot between rainfall and the other elements (Figure 3). We can see some relationships here, for example as `hmax` increases (the maximum humidity), rainfall varies more with a higher average; the reverse is seen as `ws` (wind speed) decreases. Temperature tends to have a more "parabola" relationship with rainfall - with lower rainfall generally occurring when the temperature is cooler or hotter.


Figure 3: Scatterplots of the elements by rainfall

Or by other methods, such as by looking at rainfall averages by Station, Year, or Month. These are not so clear here due to the extreme rainfall values. However, 1965-66 have less-skewed boxplots. Is this because there was more rainfall than usual so the boxplots are more skewed? Or more consistent rainfall values throughout the year?
We can additionally see the rainy seasons and trend of rainfall through the different months.


Figure 4: Boxplot of Station, Year, and Month by Rainfall

This exploration has barely scratched the surface when looking at data. It can open new questions into the data, and give more to explore. From this, hypotheses can arise to use in later stages of analysis.
